name: Barack Obama
caption:
Our medical professionals continue to put their lives on the line to make sure weâ€™re able to get through this moment. And weâ€™re so grateful for all that theyâ€™re doing to keep us safe. Today, Iâ€™ll be sharing the story of a physician on the frontlines, Dr. Sherene Fakhran.â£
â£
Dr. Fakhran specializes in pulmonary and critical care and has been working at @cookcountyhealth Hospital in Chicago for the last ten years. These last few months have been difficult, but she credits the efforts of the entire hospital - the doctors, nurses, respiratory therapists, custodians, and support staff - for doing their part to keep the hospital going to tend to COVID-19 patients in critical need. â£
â£
Dr. Fakhran shares more about her experience while working in the intensive care unit at Cook County Health: â€œA big part of what we do in the ICU is to communicate and build a relationship with the patients and families. Speaking with families has become more challenging. We also try to facilitate video calls with patients and families to help them feel connected or at times say goodbye. Although, I have been working with critically ill patients for many years, this experience has been very emotional.â€â£
â£
â€œWhat gives me the most hope is how people have come together to support in whatever way they canâ€“â€“from bringing in food to making PPE for our staff. All the providers in our division have also done an outstanding job staying positive, supporting each other, and rising up to the challenge. Most importantly, seeing some of our sickest patients recover and actually go home has been the best feeling of all.â€

name: Barack Obama
caption:
Six years ago, I started @MBK_Alliance to address the opportunity gaps facing our boys and young men of color, knowing that America could never reach its potential if they couldnâ€™t reach theirs. We wanted to make sure they werenâ€™t being left behind by helping them receive the mentorship, resources, and opportunities they deserved. â£
â£
These past few weeks, the My Brotherâ€™s Keeper Alliance has been hosting virtual town halls to check-in with community leaders looking out for communities of color that have been hit especially hard by the COVID-19 pandemic. I had a chance to join one of these calls, and it looks like this bright kid here, Avi, tuned into our conversation. Across the country, our young peopleâ€”just like Aviâ€”are listening in and watching how weâ€™re helping out during this time. Itâ€™s a reminder that this work is more important than ever, and that we must continue to support all our communities.

name: Barack Obama
caption:
â£On this day 50 years ago, millions of people from every corner of our country joined in common cause to demand basic protections to safeguard our planet for future generations. The first Earth Day helped transform the ways we interact with the world around us, and it changed how we viewed our impact on the natural worldâ€“â€“inspiring the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency and landmark legislation that protected the air we breathe, the water we drank, and the animals that lived alongside us. â €
â €
Today, weâ€™re reminded more than ever of the role we playâ€“and the responsibility of our governmentâ€“â€“to ensure that we do not pass a world beyond repair on to our children. And that starts by not denying the evidence presented by scientists and climate activists around climate change. We must demand more from our government, return to the Paris Agreement, and work to lead the world in reducing the pollution that continues to cause climate change. And science is telling us to go much furtherâ€“â€“we must continue to accelerate progress on bold new green initiatives that make our economy a clean energy innovator. â €
â €
When I think of the world I want to see in the future for my daughtersâ€“â€“and the children across the worldâ€“â€“Iâ€™m reminded that there is so much more we need to do to take care of the one planet we've got, and itâ€™s up to all of us to demand and lead that change.

name: Barack Obama
caption:
â£It doesnâ€™t take a pandemic to see how vital mentorship programs are to our communitiesâ€”they ensure young people, especially those growing up in underserved neighborhoods, donâ€™t get left behind. Iâ€™d like to share the story of one mentorship organization going above and beyond in my hometown. â €
â €
Since 2005, New Life Centers of Chicagoland, a MBK Alliance Seed Community partner organization, has been providing mentorship and outreach to kids in the Little Village, Brighton Park, Humboldt Park, and Midway neighborhoods. The idea is that mentors and youth â€œwalk togetherâ€ through lifeâ€”not just in the big moments, but through all the milestones in between so they never have to feel like theyâ€™re alone.â €
â €
New Life Centers knew that this crisis wouldnâ€™t just change the way their mentorship programming workedâ€“â€“they knew they had to adapt to meet the new needs of the youth they served. And for a lot of the families in their neighborhoods, the crisis has made a disproportionate impact. It meant hunger. It meant loss. But it didnâ€™t mean losing hope. â €
â €
Since Chicago started sheltering in place, New Life Centers has been safely distributing healthy food to more than 400 families a week. Theyâ€™ve also kept up their mentoring, tutoring, street outreach and even deployed video game consoles for virtual tournaments to keep up a little joyful communication and competition while families stay home. Theyâ€™re still making sure that no kid has to walk alone, even if they canâ€™t walk together right now. â €
â €
When you ask New Life Centers staff what keeps them motivated to see this work through, itâ€™s an answer that rings true for so many organizations just like theirs: â€œOur young people keep us motivated. We know theyâ€™re facing the same challenges we are. And thatâ€™s why we do the work. We just want to make sure they know they have someone in their corner.â€

name: Barack Obama
caption:
Iâ€™m proud to endorse my friend Joe Biden for President of the United States

If thereâ€™s one thing weâ€™ve learned as a country from moments of great crisis, itâ€™s that the American spirit of looking out for one another canâ€™t be restricted to our homes, or our workplaces, or our neighborhoods, or our houses of worship. It also has to be reflected in our national government. The kind of leadership thatâ€™s guided by knowledge and experience; honesty and humility; empathy and grace â€“ that kind of leadership doesnâ€™t just belong in our state capitols and mayors offices. It belongs in the White House.
Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m so proud to endorse @JoeBiden for President of the United States.

Choosing Joe to be my Vice President was one of the best decisions I ever made. Heâ€™s got the character and the experience to guide us through one of our darkest times and heal us through a long recovery. And Iâ€™ve got a lot more to say about why Joe should be President in the video. I hope you give it a watch. name: Barack Obama
caption:
â£We owe a profound debt of gratitude to all the people working on the frontlines. From our medical professionals to our grocery store clerks, weâ€™ve seen people step up and make endless sacrifices to help us get through this pandemic. Today, Iâ€™ll be sharing the story of one of those leaders on the frontlines and my friend, @chefjoseandres. â €â£ â €â£
Throughout this pandemic, his organization the @wckitchen has stepped up to support over 20 cities across the country. Hereâ€™s what motivates Jose and how we all can play a role in supporting our communities: â €â£ â €â£
â€œWe are living a moment that will define generations. We will look back on these days as the world changes into something new, and we will ask ourselvesâ€¦what did we do to help? To help the marginalized and vulnerable, to help the heroes working on the front lines, to help the huddled masses among us? â €â£ â €â£
From Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico to the wildfires in California, to tornadoes and floods across the country to a humanitarian crisis on our southern border, World Central Kitchenâ€™s journey to serving over 15 million meals has taught us one essential lesson: instead of being paralyzed by the magnitude of a problem, we can choose to be part of the solution by coming together to just start cooking.â€ â €â£ â €â£
â€œThere are so, so many ways you can help. Buy a meal for the medical professionals and first responders working day and night to keep us healthy and safe. Check in on elderly neighbors to make sure they arenâ€™t forgotten. Wash your hands. Stay home if you can and listen to the experts, always. Being kind and caring for one another. Make sure to leave enough for the next person. Your empathy will reach beyond six feet!â€

name: Barack Obama
caption:
The Reverend Joseph Lowery was born and raised in Jim Crow Alabama with no power or privilege to speak of. But he had preaching in his blood. He had a conviction that he could join and inspire others to push for change.
From those early days of the movement to his long leadership of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, he did so much to carry us ever closer to the just, fair, inclusive, and generous America promised in our founding ideals.
Reverend Lowery changed the face of America. He carried the baton longer and surer than almost anybody. It falls to the rest of us now to pick it up and never stop moving forward until we finish what he startedâ€“that journey to justice. Michelle and I remember him fondly today, and our love and prayers are with his family and his nationwide flock.

name: Barack Obama
caption:
55 years ago, in Selma, Alabama, John Lewis and Amelia Boynton Robinson were two of the many civil rights organizers who were beaten for the simple act of attempting to cross the Edmund Pettus Bridge. In 2015, Michelle and I, along with Michelleâ€™s mother and our girls â€“ three generations, hand-in-hand â€“ joined these heroes to walk the path that they had paved.
The story of Selma is quintessentially American â€“ itâ€™s the story of ordinary people coming together to shape our nationâ€™s course because they believed in the simple idea that people who love their country can change it.
Today, the march goes on. But the way forward is a little easier, thanks to all those who came before us, who sacrificed everything for the foundation stone of democracy â€“ the right to vote. Now itâ€™s up to us to honor their legacy by protecting and exercising that precious right, knowing that the work of perfecting our union is never done.

name: Barack Obama
caption:
Six years ago today, we launched the My Brotherâ€™s Keeper initiative at the White House, a call on us all to recognize that America would never live up to its potential unless our boys and young men of color could live up to theirs. We all have a stake in their success. We are all our brotherâ€™s keeper.
This photo was taken at a gathering of the young people whose lives that work has touched, many of them now leaders and mentors themselves. When I entered the auditorium, I saw a room full of promising young men who deserved a nation willing to embrace them, invest in their dreams, and love them as their own.

name: Barack Obama
caption:
Last night, I had the chance to sit down with Stacey Abrams to talk about how Democrats can win up and down the ballot in 2020. Thereâ€™s a lot of great work already happening: Staceyâ€™s Fair Fight effort to end voter suppression, Eric Holderâ€™s National Democratic Redistricting Committee to draw fair maps, and a lot of big-hearted, forward-looking candidates and campaigns to get people registered and out to the polls.â£
â£
The truth is we win when people vote. The more energized we are, the better organized we are as a party, the better the outcome. We believe in the ideals of equality and democracy, freedom of thought and religion. We rally around the notion that we are all bound together and a belief that civil argument can lead us to a more perfect union. We commit ourselves to the principles that are embodied in our Constitution. And we have to remember that our faith is tested at hard times, not at easy times. Thatâ€™s how this works. So I hope all of usâ€”as citizens, as volunteers, as Americans who simply believe that we can make this country betterâ€”are ready to get marching, get organizing, and get voting. Itâ€™s up to us.

name: Bernie Sanders
caption: â€œHi Bernie. My name is Jiye. I am a pediatric nurse and I have personally witnessed countless patients of mine - the kiddos I love - get rejected from health insurance companies the life-saving treatments and drugs they need. I have seen parents cry and worry about the health care costs and still bringing their kids to the hospital, knowing that they will get a 'surprise medical bill' arriving at their doorstep very soon. If we as a country cannot care for the weakest members - the sick children - we are worth nothing. I believe that. Please continue to fight for us. I dream of the day, I can tell the parents of sick children - that they can focus on making sure the children get better, instead of having to fight with insurance companies. Thank you for fighting for us. Thank you for standing up to those who donâ€™t care about anything but profits and money. name: Bernie Sanders
caption: It was an honor to join our volunteer canvassers at our Al Johnson Greater Nashua field office today. Everyone here is heading out this afternoon to talk to voters about tomorrow's primary. That passion for democracy was Al Johnson's passion. Despite struggling with Stage 4 cancer, Al would spend nearly every weekend canvassing and organizing for our movement. Just a day before he passed on January 1st, 2020, Al made 200 calls for our campaign. Thank you, Al, and thank you to all of our volunteers for everything you are doing to revitalize democracy.

name: Bernie Sanders
caption:
Iâ€™ve gone to too many funerals in my own state. Iâ€™ve talked to too many mothers who have lost their kids in war. Iâ€™ve talked to too many soldiers, men and women, who have come home with PTSD, who have come home without arms and without legs.

And I know that it is rarely the children of the billionaire class who face the agony of reckless foreign policy. It is the children of working families.

I believe the role of the United States, difficult though it may be, must be to work with the international community to end conflicts, to end the threat of war, not to promote war as Trump is doing.

This is how the true power of the United States is shown, and that is how I will use American power as president.

name: Bernie Sanders
caption:
#BernieYearinReview
Bernie's Back in Queens, New York, October 19
.
â€œI want you all to take a look around and find someone you donâ€™t know. Maybe somebody who doesnâ€™t look kind of like you, maybe somebody who might be of a different religion than you, maybe they come from a different country. My question now to you is: Are you willing to fight for that person who you donâ€™t even know as much as youâ€™re willing to fight for yourself? Are you willing to stand together and fight for those people who are struggling economically in this country? Are you willing to fight for young people drowning in student debt, even if you are not? Are you willing to fight to ensure that every American has health care as a human right, even if you have good health care? Are you willing to fight for frightened immigrant neighbors, even if you are native born? Are you willing to fight for a future for generations of people who have not yet even been born, but are entitled to live on a planet that is healthy and habitable? Because if you are willing to do that, if you are willing to love, if you are willing to fight for a government of compassion and justice and decency, if you are willing to stand up to Trump's desire to divide us up, if you are prepared to stand up to the greed and corruption of the corporate elite, if you and millions of others are prepared to do that, there is no doubt in my mind that not only will we win this election, but together we will transform this country."

name: Bernie Sanders
caption:
#BernieYearInReview
Traveling to Canada for Affordable Insulin, July 28

This summer I boarded a bus with patients with diabetes struggling to afford their insulin. In Detroit, where we began, this vial of insulin costs $340. Twenty minutes away in Ontario, Canada, we purchased the exact same vial for $32. That is nothing but outrageous and scandalous greed by the pharmaceutical industry, and when we are in the White House that greed is going to end.

name: Bernie Sanders
caption:
#BernieYearInReview
Kickoff at Navy Pier in Chicago, March 3

My time at the University of Chicago, at the height of the Civil Rights Movement, changed my life and helped shape me into the person I am today.

In 1963 I was a student at the University of Chicago. It had been nine years since the Brown v Board of Education decision, but the school officials in Chicago had still refused to meaningfully desegregate the cityâ€™s public schools. Instead of putting black children in those empty classrooms, the school officials decided to put old trailers on the black school grounds. These trailers were a monstrosity. Students would boil in the heat, and freeze in the cold.

One day, many of us went to the spot where they planned to put the trailers. We were corralled by a police line and told not to cross that line. Well, some of us did. And, of course, we were arrested and thrown into paddy wagons. We spent that night in jail, until we were bailed out the next morning by the NAACP.

My activities in Chicago taught me a very important lesson. And that is that whether it is the struggle is against racism, or sexism, or homophobia, or corporate greed, or environmental devastation, or war and militarism or religious bigotry - real change never takes place from the top on down. It always takes place from the bottom on up when people, at the grassroots level, stand up and fight back. That's a lesson I learned in Chicago, and a lesson I've never forgotten.

name: Bernie Sanders
caption:
What we are seeing right now, in America and all over the world, is a rise in anti-semitism. Weâ€™re seeing a rise in hate crimes. Weâ€™re seeing somebody run into a kid in Des Moines because that child is Latina. Weâ€™re seeing people being stabbed yesterday in New York because they are Jewish. And we are seeing people being assaulted because they are Muslim.

If there was ever a time in American history where we say no to religious bigotry, this is the time. If there was ever a time when we say no to divisiveness, this is that moment.

So I was delighted to be in Des Moines with Rabbi Yossi Jacobson tonight to celebrate the lighting of the Hanukkah candles, and to once again reaffirm our belief in an America where justice, freedom and religious freedom apply to all peopleâ€”and to stand united to wipe out all forms of racism, discrimination and bigotry.

name: Bernie Sanders
caption:
#BernieYearInReview
Visiting Ruins of Paradise, California, August 22

Paradise, California was nearly destroyed by a wildfire that killed 86 people, the deadliest wildfire in California history. Climate change is lengthening wildfire seasons, increasing the heat and drought that fuels the fires, and putting more towns and lives at risk. If thereâ€™s any silver lining in this terrible tragedy in this beautiful town it is that, I hope, the people of the United States, the people of the world, understand that we need bold and aggressive action â€” a Green New Deal â€” to combat climate change.

name: Bernie Sanders
caption:
#BernieYearInReview
Honoring the Victims of Lynchings in Montgomery, Alabama, May 20

As we traveled in Alabama, I had the opportunity to visit the National Memorial for Peace and Justice in Montgomery and must admit I was shaken. It is a memorial of terrorism in the United States of America and a monument to the memories of 4,400 African Americans who were lynched since Reconstruction. It is a memorial of the horrors of American history that we have got to understand. We cannot go forward if we sweep history under the rug.

caption:
#BernieYearInReview
Water Crisis in Denmark, SC, May 19

That is what people in Denmark, South Carolina, have to do because the state government pumped a dangerous chemical into the cityâ€™s water supply. It is not a radical idea to say in the 21st century, people in the wealthiest nation on earth should be able to drink water that is clean and does not make them sick. We will repair our crumbling water infrastructure and guarantee clean water as a right with a Green New Deal.

name: Joe Biden
caption:
Fifty years ago, the first Earth Day took place against a backdrop of unfettered pollution filling our skies, rivers so poisonous they caught fire, unregulated use of pesticides, and threats to the livability of our planet. But in a moment of choice, Americans all across this country took action. On April 22, 1970, 20 million people turned out to educate their communities and protest the degradation of our planet, launching the modern environmental movement.

It wasnâ€™t a partisan issue. It wasnâ€™t some ideological debate. Everyone could see that our planet was in peril. And by acting together, those activists seized the attention and the imagination of people all over the world, as well as leaders in Washington. Out of that first Earth Day came the Environmental Protection Agency, the Clean Air Act of 1970, the Clean Water Act, the Endangered Species Act, and a new mindset that awakened all of us to our responsibilities beyond just the world we leave our children â€” to ensuring that our one planet will provide for generations unborn.

This year, Earth Day comes amid global crises: the difficult, immediate, and undeniable reality of pandemic disease, and the existential threat of climate change â€” which we are already experiencing and which threatens equally deadly results in the near future if we fail to act. COVID-19 and the climate emergency both underscore the fragility of life on this planet, the connections that bind us to our fellow humans, and the responsibility we all have to meet these global threats with urgent action, ambitious plans, and every tool at our disposal.

Thatâ€™s the responsibility I feel every time I look at my grandchildren and see their unlimited potential. Or when I hear from young activists who understand that inaction today is costing their futures. Todayâ€™s young people carry the same fierce spirit as those first Earth Day activists, and they are the reason I know we will succeed in spurring the world to finally raise our ambitions to meet the seriousness of this threat.

Read more: [Link in Bio]

name: Joe Biden
caption:
Iâ€™ve had a chance to get to know Bernie over the years. We were in the Senate together before Barack and I took office, and of course, I had known him from his work in the House. What I liked about Bernie was that he said what he believed, no matter who was in the room. I admired his passion. I liked his convictions. I thought people who failed to take him seriously would prove to be sorely mistaken. And, as it turns out, I was right.

Senator Sanders endorsed our campaign today and I want to thank him not just for the endorsement, but for his leadership on making our country a more just, fairer place.

Itâ€™s voices like his that refuse to allow us to just accept what is â€” that refuse to accept we canâ€™t change whatâ€™s wrong in our nation â€” and that refuse to accept the health and well-being of our fellow citizens and our planet isnâ€™t our responsibility too.
He doesn't get enough credit for being a voice that forces us all to take a hard look in the mirror and ask if weâ€™ve done enough. He has put the interest of the nation â€” and the need to defeat Donald Trump â€” above all else.
Iâ€™m excited to continue the work Bernie started in the months and years ahead. As he says: Not me, Us.

And to Bernieâ€™s supporters I make the same commitment: I see you, I hear you, and I understand the urgency of what it is we have to get done in this country.
I hope you will join us: [Link in Bio]. You are more than welcome on this campaign. Youâ€™re needed.

name: Joe Biden
caption:
The church is all about hope.
We can come back together as a nation to reassert the values that define us as Americans. American history is not a fairy tale.

At our best, the American ideal wins out. But the fight is never over. And I know as well as anyone that when we fight, when we hope, things can change for the better. I think back to January 2009, when I was standing in the spot in Wilmington, Delaware, that had burned to the ground in 1968, waiting for a black man to come some 20 miles from Philadelphia to pick me up for the train ride to Washington, DC, to be inaugurated as President and Vice President of the United States.
We have to keep fighting. And we have to keep hoping. The church is all about hope.

name: Joe Biden
caption:
Health care is personal to me. I was sworn into the United States Senate next to a hospital bed. My wife and daughter had been killed in a car crash â€” and lying in that bed were my two surviving little boys. I couldnâ€™t imagine what it would have been like if we didnâ€™t have the health care we needed immediately.

Forty years later, one of those little boys, my son Beau, was diagnosed with terminal cancer and given only months to live. Through the hardship, I saw firsthand how important it is to have quality, affordable coverage â€” it means peace of mind that your medical bills wonâ€™t drown you in debt and helps provide hope that things will get better.

This fight is personal to me â€” like it is for so many Americans. And I promise you that if Iâ€™m elected president, I will protect your familyâ€™s health care coverage as if it were my own.

['Joe Hurry home , Hunter needs BAIL $$$$$$$', 'Medicare For All Would Save More Than 68,000 Lives And $450 Billion Every Year, According To New Study
HEALTH AND MEDICINE

At a Medicare for All rally in June, 2019, people held up signs of support for the movement. ShellyShoots/ Shutterstock
By Katy Pallister
 17 Feb 2020, 17:19
ADVERTISMENT
Epidemiologists from the Yale School of Public Health, University of Florida, and University of Maryland School of Medicine, have calculated that a single-payer universal health-care system in the US would likely lead to a 13 percent saving in national health-care expenditure and prevent more than 68,000 unnecessary deaths. By replacing premiums, deductibles, co-payments and out-of-pocket costs with a progressive tax system, Medicare for All will not only save the average family around $2,400 a year, but also give lower-income families access to the services they need, the researchers say.
Published in The Lancet, the study first sets out the current state of affairs. Over 78 million Americans (24 percent of the US population), do not have adequate access to care. This number includes over 37 million Americans who have no health insurance at all. However, the situation could get worse. â€œThe move to repeal the Affordable Care Act by the Trump administration will further jeopardize the health care of 21 million Americans,â€ the researchers warned in the paper, which would â€œexacerbate health-care inequities.â€
Already the USA ranks poorly for many public health indicators, such as preventable deaths, infant survival, and maternal mortality, given its national health expenditure is higher than any other country. Repealing the Affordable Care Act would result in an additional loss of more than 38,500 lives, the team writes in their paper. However, employing the Medicare for All Act would save over 68,500 lives, compared to the status quo.
This life-saving effect that the Medicare for All Act would achieve is calculated from just one group of people: those that are uninsured. In this group, people are reported to experience a 40 percent elevation in age-specific mortality risk. If all Americans became insured, the universal coverage would save tens of thousands.', 'Saturdays are for sniffies.', 'Joe is the only candidate that can strengthen America to its finest can increase its ecomic growth. #joebiden', 'Part of the farewell tour. #winoneforthegroper', 'ğŸ¤¡ğŸ¤¡ğŸ¤¡', '#neverbiden', 'NOW ALL THE WORLD. caption: Child care is personal to me. I was a single parent as a young senator after my wife and daughter passed away in an automobile accident. I commuted over 220 miles a day on Amtrak â€” between Wilmington, Delaware, and Washington D.C. â€” to be there for my two boys and to tuck them into bed at night. I was lucky to have my sister Valerie around to help, but I know not every single parent is so lucky. I understand the difficult choices a parent has to make in order to give their kids the best possible start in life. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m committed to making child care affordable for every parent and providing high-quality, universal pre-kindergarten for all three- and four-year-olds.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Government delivers best when its actions are fair, transparent, and accountable. Donald Trumpâ€™s approach to COVID-19 been anything but.

As senators overseeing the executive branch and as executive officials answering to independent oversight, @JoeBiden and I know oversight is vital. As we both argued in the primary, we must end corruption and guarantee a government that works for the people.

We must take broad, urgent action to stop the Trump administrationâ€™s corruption. Swipe up through the link in my Instagram Story to read my new op-ed with @JoeBiden.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
My oldest brother, Don Reed, died from coronavirus on Tuesday evening. He joined the Air Force at 19 and spent his career in the military, including five and a half years off and on in combat in Vietnam (thatâ€™s him, on my right). He was charming and funny, a natural leader.

What made him extra special was his smileâ€”quick and crooked, it always seemed to generate its own light, one that lit up everyone around him.
Iâ€™m grateful to the nurses and frontline staff who took care of him, but itâ€™s hard to know that there was no family to hold his hand or to say â€œI love youâ€ one more timeâ€”and no funeral for those of us who loved him to hold each other close. Iâ€™ll miss you dearly my brother.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Our health care, janitorial, delivery, mail, transportation, farm, grocery, and domestic workers are on the front lines of this pandemic. Rep. @RoKhannaUSA and I are urging Congress to enact needed protections for them in the next coronavirus relief package. Essential workers are working in high-risk conditions without appropriate equipment, safety standards, or job protections. Some reports indicate that they may be contracting COVID-19 at a higher rate than the general public.

Thatâ€™s why we are proposing an Essential Workers Bill of Rights, focusing on ten key areas affecting frontline workersâ€”including additional health and safety protections, robust premium pay, truly universal paid sick leave and family and medical leave, and more. Essential workers are the backbone of our nationâ€™s response to coronavirus. We have a responsibility to make sure they have the protections they need, the rights they are entitled to, and the compensation they deserve.

The next relief package must put all workers front and centerâ€”but it must also specifically include the policies in our Essential Workers Bill of Rights. Learn more through the link in my bio.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
As federal, state, and local governments rightfully issue stay-at-home orders and encourage residents to practice social distancing to combat the virus, large-scale, in-person voting on election day could present serious risks to public health. No American should have to choose between participating in our democracy and keeping themselves safe and healthy.

Our government needs to act immediately to ensure elections can proceed safely, securely, and on-time. But Donald Trump and right-wing Republicans are already using the crisis to disenfranchise millions. The task of protecting our democracy has never been more vital. Congress must do its partâ€”and governors and state officials must also step up to protect our elections.

In the next coronavirus relief package, Iâ€™m fighting for a plan to protect the health and safety of voters and strengthen our democracy for the long haul. Learn more about our efforts through the link in my bio.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Our Military

A president's first job is to keep America safe, and an important part of that is to have a strong military. All three of my brothers served in the military and I understand how much the military sacrifices, how much their families sacrifice, and how much they are willing to put on the line.

We have a sacred responsibility to our military: To not use our military to solve problems that cannot be solved militarily. We are not winning in Afghanistan. We are not winning in the Middle East. #DemDebate

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Mike Bloomberg is the Riskiest Candidate

Mike Bloomberg is the riskiest candidate standing on today's #DemDebate stage.
Donald Trump is going to be here in Charleston, South Carolina later this week to raise money for his buddy Senator Lindsey Graham. Who funded Lindsey Graham's campaign for re-election last time? It was Mike Bloomberg. And that's not the only right-wing senator he's funded. In 2016, he dumped $12 million into the Pennsylvania Senate race to help re-elect an anti-choice, right-wing Republican senator. The woman challenger was terrificâ€”she lost by a single point.
In 2012, Bloomberg scooped in to try to defend another Republican senator against a woman challenger. Me. It didn't work, but he tried hard. I don't care how much money Bloomberg hasâ€”the core of the Democratic Party will never trust him. He has not earned their trust.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
We Need a President Who Will Get Things Done

Bernie and I both wanted to help rein in Wall Street. In 2008, we both got our chance. But I dug in, I fought the big banks, I built the coalitions, and I won.
Bernie and I both want to see universal health care. But Bernie's plan doesn't explain how to get there, doesn't show how we're going to get enough allies into it, and doesn't show enough about how we're going to pay for it. I dug in and did the work.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Environmental Justice

I want to make sure the question of environmental justice gets more than a glancing blow in this debate. Because for generations now in this country, toxic waste dumps and polluting factories have been located in or near communities of color, over and over.

I have a commitment of a trillion dollars to repair the damage that this nation has permitted to inflict on communities of color for generations. We have to own up to our responsibility. We cannot simply talk about climate change in big, global terms. We need to talk about it in terms of rescuing the communities that have been damaged. #DemDebate

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
When Mike Bloomberg says that he apologized, listen very closely to the apology. The language he used is about how stop and frisk turned out.
But this isn't about how it turned out. This is about what it was designed to do to begin with. It targeted communities of color. It targeted Black and Brown men from the beginning.
If you want to issue a real apology, the apology has to start with the intent of the plan as it was put together and the willful ignorance of admitting what was happening even as people protested in your streets, of you shutting out the sounds of people telling you how your own policy was breaking their lives.
You need a different apology here, Mr. Mayor. #DemDebate

caption:
We Need Unshakeable Values

While Mike Bloomberg was busy blaming African Americans and Latinos for the housing crash of 2008, I was right here in Las Vegas, holding hearings on the banks that were taking away homes from millions of families.
I spent the following years making sure that would never happen again. Wall Street fought us every inch of the way. But they lost, and I won. We need a candidate with unshakeable values and a candidate who can actually get something done for working people. #DemDebate

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Who We're Running Against

Here's who we're running against: A billionaire who calls women "fat broads" and "horse-faced lesbians." I'm not talking about Donald Trump. I'm talking about Mike Bloomberg.
Democrats are not going to win if we have a nominee who has a history of hiding his tax returns, of harassing women, and of supporting racist policies like redlining and stop and frisk.
I'll support whoever the nominee is, but understand this: Democrats take a huge risk if we just substitute one arrogant billionaire for another. It's time to have a president who is on the side of working familiesâ€”and is willing to get out there and fight for them. #DemDebate

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Ending Mass Incarceration

The United States has the highest incarceration rate in the world. If we want to end mass incarceration, we can't just nibble around the edges of this problemâ€”we need to reform the system from front to back. And I've got a plan for that.
comments: ['She clearly has never worked, lived, or had to move around. In high crime areas. Why should these people not be locked up', 'â¤ï¸', 'ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ‘', '@berniesanders where you at Bro!', "Yeah the no bail plan is working great in New York. We don't have any issues. The problem is people don't think they need to follow laws because we have given youth the impression that in America you are free to do whatever you want and have a right to be happy at any cost. This lie has been taught in schools, music, and movies. We don't have a right to happiness, we have the right to pursue happiness within the confines of our laws and civility. We are also free to do what we want, but there are consequences. Unfortunately, we have a culture that protects children and young adults from dealing with consequences when they make adult choices so they never learn. What we need is a cultural change. Decriminalization isn't working in new York, California is a mess because of it, and last I checked Colorado was making bank, but the negative stats are all up after decriminalizing drug use.", "@gudsoncarter There are many private prisons that are for-profit entities. name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Put Real Money Into the Future of Our Children

I learned early on about the worth of every single human being, and I believe that the best investment we can make as a nation and as human beings is in our children. Everyone says they love our kids, but here's the deal: It's time to come up with real plans to make that happen.

Don't leave public education just to our localities and states. Be a good federal partner. Put real money into our schools. Put real money into housing. Put real money into health care. Put real money into the future of our children. That's how we build the America of our best values. #DemDebate

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Our Democracy Hangs in the Balance

I don't think anyone ought to be able to buy their way into a nomination or to be president. I don't think people who suck up to billionaires in order to fund their campaigns ought to do it.
Our democracy hangs in the balance. If we have to fund through billionaires, then we're just going to be an America that works better for billionaires and not for anyone else. #DemDebate

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
We Have a Gun Violence Problem

We have a gun violence problem in America. And Americans across the country agree on universal background checks and getting assault weapons off the streets.
But until we attack the corruption in Washington, the influence of money on campaigns and lobbying, and until we agree to roll back the filibuster, the gun industry is going to continue to have a veto and we'll never make the changes.
We have to be willing to build a future that works not for the gun industry, but for the rest of America and protects our children. #DemDebate

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Race has totally permeated our criminal justice system. For the exact same crime, study after study now shows that African Americans are more likely than whites to be detained, to be arrested, to be taken to trial, to be wrongfully convicted and receive harsher sentences.
We need to rework our criminal justice system from the very front end on what we make illegal, and all the way through the system and how we help people come back into the community. But we cannot just say criminal justice is the only time we want to talk about race specifically. We need to start having race-conscious laws. #DemDebate

We need Elizabeth Warren in the White House to correct things. We need her progressive policies and improved capitalist ideas that will work for everyone. name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Disinformation and online foreign interference erode our democracy, and Donald Trump has invited both. Anyone who seeks to challenge and defeat Donald Trump must be prepared to take on the full array of disinformation that foreign actors and people in and around his campaign will use to divide Democrats, suppress Democratic votes, and erode the standing of the Democratic nominee.
So today, Iâ€™m making a pledge: I will not knowingly use or spread disinformation to benefit my own candidacy or damage others. And I will fight disinformation aimed at my campaign, my opponents, and voters.
Iâ€™m sending a clear message to anyone associated with the Warren campaign: I will not tolerate the use of false information or false accounts to attack my opponents, promote my campaign, or undermine our elections. And I urge my fellow candidates to do the same.

I'm also calling on tech companies like Facebook, Twitter, and Google to take real steps right now to fight disinformation spread on their platforms. The safety of our democracy is more important than shareholder dividends and CEO salaries. And as president, I'll take a series of actions to further address the spread of disinformation.

The stakes of this election are too high. We need to fight the spread of false information that disempowers voters and undermines democracy. Iâ€™ll do my partâ€”and Iâ€™m calling on my fellow candidates and big tech companies to do their part, too. Read my full pledge at the link in the bio.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Jenny | Team Warren

Our health care system is immoral and inefficient, and it is costing lives. No one should be able to make a profit off of denying people health care. I'm fighting for #MedicareForAll for families like Jenny's.
comments: ['ğŸ˜­', 'Amen amen amen! Medicare for all!', 'Yeah, because the Government has been so good at what? Stealing money and wasting it on Illegal Aliens?', '@mcstanton_8', 'ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­', 'When you have lost your home and have to live in your car due to the high cost of healthcare, something is seriously wrong.', 'â¤ï¸ğŸ™â¤ï¸', 'Thank you, Iâ€™m counting on that more than you know ğŸ•Š', 'ğŸ˜ğŸ˜', 'At 24, my husband was diagnosed with an aggressive Hodgkins lymphoma. Because we were military, ALL of his treatment and medications were covered at our civilian hospitals. His care over those two years was well over $2 million that was COMPLETELY COVERED. One month of medications alone totaled over $11k that was COMPLETELY COVERED. The Army allowed us to move home to do treatment. At the time of his diagnosis, we had an 11 month old and I was high risk with our second son (I paid $38 for both deliveries and NICU care for our first). I will NEVER be against access-for-all healthcare. Neither will my husband. At 24, with both of us college educated and veterans, we wouldâ€™ve had to choose between treating cancer and living on the street with a young family. He needed one more dose of chemo after being medically retired and we couldnâ€™t afford the copay. name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
To effectively beat infectious diseases like coronavirus, we need all hands on deck. But like so much else, Donald Trumpâ€™s approach to keeping us safe from disease outbreaks is a mess. Trump has deprioritized global health security, repeatedly tried to nickel and dime essential federal programs, refused to confront climate change, and done almost nothing in response to natural disasters that could lead to serious outbreaks, like the hurricanes in Puerto Rico.
When he's gone, we must fix the damage he's done. Thatâ€™s why I have a plan to prevent and prepare for outbreaks, contain them if they do break out, and push for medical advances to treat emerging infectious diseases. It's time to invest in keeping Americans safe and healthy. Read my full plan at the link in the bio.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
One year from today, the next president will begin her first full day of work. Sheâ€™ll inherit a government in crisis, infected by corruption and incompetence. Sheâ€™ll need the expertise and drive to rebuild our government and ensure it works for the people. And I've got a plan for that.

I know how to get our government working for the people because Iâ€™ve done it before. In 2010, President Obama picked me to get the CFPB up and running. We recruited a mission-driven staff and set up the organization, and it acted swiftly to protect Americans from financial predators.

On day one of my presidency, I will take aggressive steps to root out the corruption and incompetence of the Trump administration and to hold that administration accountable, starting by removing all political appointees except those positions necessary to preserve continuity and protect national security during the transition period. I will also direct the Justice Department to establish an independent task force to investigate violations of specific anti-corruption and public integrity laws during the Trump administration, with independent authority to pursue any substantiated violations.
I'll move swiftly to appoint new personnel who will undo the Trump administration's disastrous policies, and I'll adopt the strictest anti-corruption hiring rules of any administration in American history. I'll appoint people who want to fulfill their agency's mission, not undermine it. And I'll build a Cabinet and senior leadership team that reflects the full diversity of America.

Donald Trumpâ€™s presidency has been a dark timeâ€”but it wonâ€™t end just because he's left office. Rooting out corruption and incompetence, rebuilding our government, and ensuring it will work for the people will require painstaking work. I've got a serious plan to get it done. Read my full plan at the link in the bio.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Black Wall Street

Nearly 100 years ago, mobs of white residents descended on Black Wall Street in Tulsa, Oklahoma, ransacking Black businesses and murdering hundreds of African Americans. The Tulsa Race Massacre was one of the worst incidents of racist violence in our nation's history. I had the chance to visit the site of the Tulsa Race Massacreâ€”a terrible chapter in our nation's history.
While we can never undo this hateful act of domestic terrorism or the pain and suffering it inflicted on the Black community, we all must do our part to dismantle the legacy of systemic racism and oppression that was left in its wakeâ€”and that starts with justice and opportunity.
The men responsible for killing hundreds of innocent African Americans committed an act of domestic terrorism, but they were never held accountable. The search for the victimsâ€™ mass graves continues to this day, as does the domestic terrorism threat of white nationalism. In a Warren administration, we will use every tool we have to defeat white nationalist violence and associated acts of terror.
Black Wall Street was defined by the human spirit. So the community was rebuilt relatively quickly, peaking in the 1940s. But it declined in the sixties and seventies because of gentrification and failure to have a systematic mentorship process in place.

For generations, the federal government has prevented African Americans from building wealth and financial security. It's time for our government to acknowledge its actions and step in to make opportunity available for African American communities. And we do that by investing in Black Americans and creating opportunity. The fights for social, racial, and economic justice belong to all of usâ€”and when Iâ€™m president, that truth will inform our policies and our actions.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
We have a student loan crisisâ€”and we can't afford to wait for Congress to act. Iâ€™ve already proposed a student loan debt cancellation plan, and on day one of my presidency, Iâ€™ll use existing laws to start providing that debt cancellation immediately.
When I was elected to the Senate, I used every opportunity and tool available to ease the burden of student debt. I fought to lower interest rates, refinance loans, and hold loan servicers and debt collectors accountable for breaking the law and hurting borrowers. I made sure Congress provided $700 million in a relief fund for borrowers who dedicated their lives to public service but missed technical requirements for loan forgiveness, and I fought to cancel loans for 80,000 students who were cheated by Corinthian Colleges.

Understand this: The Department of Education has broad authority to end the student loan debt crisis. When I'm president, I plan to use that authority. I will also use all the tools available to me to address the racial disparities in higher education, crack down on for-profit institutions, and eliminate predatory lending.

The future of our economy and a generation of student loan borrowers are at risk, and we must use every tool and opportunity we have to help them. We can't let corruption in Washington hold back big, structural change. Iâ€™m committed to seeing this fight throughâ€”no matter what. Check out the link in my bio to see how weâ€™ll do it.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
A Green New Economy

I've got a plan to create 10.6 million green jobs, and @RGunnerâ€”one of the architects of the #GreenNewDealâ€”is here to answer your questions about how we can build a green new economy together!
comments: ['This actually addresses a lot of my concerns about moving back to the US. Iâ€™ve been living in Germany for the last nine years. Here I have learned a trade (which I was paid for!), found love, had a child, and have had amazing healthcare (oh, Iâ€™m also actually bilingual now). Meanwhile, my income is meager ( I guess by German standards Iâ€™m hovering just above the poverty line) but I have been able to afford everything I need without having to go into any debt whatsoever. My move to Germany came after putzing around at my local community college just after high school. While I enjoyed the education I was receiving, I struggled with deciding on a major. Not knowing what direction I wanted to take my education in, I couldnâ€™t rationalize continuing on to a 4-year just to get a degree in whatever, all the while accumulating heinous amounts of debt that there would be no way of knowing how long it would take me to repay. My move was not intended to be permanent [truth be told, I came to Germany to study because itâ€™s ridiculously affordable (I mean, if youâ€™re gonna get a degree in whatever, you should be at least able to afford it, right?)], but one thing lead to the next and I learned a trade and started a family. That said, I am an American and I miss my home. I am trying to figure out a way to move my family State side, but I have not been able to find a way that we can afford our humble life without going into massive amounts of debt. I am an only child and my parents are getting older. Beyond loving and respecting them as human beings, I am really the only one responsible for their care as they get older. name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
I spent most of my career studying why American families go broke. What I discovered was that they weren't reckless or irresponsibleâ€”they were being squeezed by an economy that forced them to take on more debt, and one bad break sent them tumbling over the edge. Right now, our bankruptcy laws make it harder for struggling families to get back on their feet. That's not right. So today, Iâ€™m sharing my plan to overhaul our consumer bankruptcy rules.

My plan will make it easier for people being crushed by debt to obtain relief through bankruptcy by streamlining the process, reducing the costs of filing, and giving people more flexibility in bankruptcy to find solutions that match their financial problems. Iâ€™ll expand peopleâ€™s rights to take care of themselves and their children while they are in the bankruptcy process, and let them protect their homes and cars in bankruptcy so they can rebuild their financial lives. Iâ€™ll end the absurd rules that make it nearly impossible to discharge student loan debt in bankruptcy, and address the shameful racial and gender disparities that plague our bankruptcy system. And Iâ€™ll close the loopholes that allow the wealthy and corporate creditors to abuse the bankruptcy system at the expense of everyone else.
The banking industry wants you to believe people who file for bankruptcy are reckless or irresponsible. The truth is that they're struggling with rising costs and flat wages. One crisis is enough to send them over the edge. They donâ€™t need shaming. They need relief.  Read my full plan at the link in the bio.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Sarah sent me a letter asking me to make sure that people with disabilities like her brother aren't left behind.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
Disability activists have organized for decades to fight injustice. This year marks the 30th anniversary of the ADA, and although we've made significant progress, we still have a lot of ground left to cover. As president, protecting the rights and equality of people with disabilities will be a top priority.
My administration will partner with the disability community to fight ableism and for justice across all aspects of life. Together, weâ€™ll fight for economic security for individuals with disabilities, ensuring they can participate fully in the economy, receive fair wages, and have financial security for all. Weâ€™ll support children with disabilities and their families by providing crucial early interventions and ensuring meaningful access to education. Weâ€™ll ensure that technology is used to advance the interests of people with disabilitiesâ€”not to discriminate against them.

From criminal justice to voting, immigration, and protecting parents with disabilities from discrimination, weâ€™ll safeguard the rights and civil liberties of people with disabilities and work to ensure that our society and democracy are truly inclusive. Weâ€™ll promote affordable, accessible, and green housing and strengthen anti-discrimination protections. Weâ€™ll fight for #MedicareForAll to ensure that everyone has affordable, high quality health care. And the United States will lead the fight for disability rights around the world.

We all do better when everyone has the opportunity to fully participate in all aspects of life, and together, we can realize a truly inclusive world. Read the full plan at the link in my bio and help spread the word.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
What are your aspirations and dreams for 2020?

If you weren't stretched to make ends meet, who would you be? If you weren't crushed by debt, what would you do? If you lived without worrying if you could afford the health care and prescriptions you need, how could you thrive?

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
As a working mom, I cycled through one child care arrangement after another. Each felt like a failure to me: A sitter who never showed up, a neighbor who changed her mind, a child care center that left my son Alex in dirty diapers all day. And I would have kept getting smacked down by child care if it wasnâ€™t for my Aunt Bee who came down from Oklahoma to help.

Letâ€™s be clear: My plan for #UniversalChildCare will make high-quality child care free for millions of families and affordable for everyone.

name: Elizabeth Warren
caption:
When faced with seemingly impossible challenges, American ingenuity has risen to meet themâ€”and we can do it again. Defeating the climate crisis will be a top priority in my administration, and Iâ€™ve got a plan to enact a climate agenda that will not only reduce our carbon emissions, but will also jumpstart our economy and create 10.6 million new jobs.

We will rebuild and repower our energy grid and upgrade our transportation, building, and water systems. We will transform our countryâ€™s infrastructure, guard against the worst effects of climate change, and protect our most vulnerable communities. And we will create millions of good, union jobs with strong wages and benefits in the process.
The #GreenNewDeal isn't just an agenda for reducing carbon emissions and defeating the climate crisisâ€”it's an opportunity to transform and rebuild our economy. Read and spread the word about my new plan at the link in my bio.

The best way to prevent COVID-19 is to avoid being exposed. You can help prevent the spread of COVID-19 with these actions: Practice social distancing by putting space between yourself and others, avoid close contact with people who are sick, wash hands often for at least 20 seconds, and avoid touching your face. Stay safe and healthy during the COVID-19 outbreak. www.cdc.gov/coronavirus

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Today marks both Texas Independence Day and the 227th birthday of Sam Houston, the founding father of the Lone Star State.
184 years ago, Texans gathered at Washington-on-the-Brazos to boldly declare independence from Mexico.
During this time, legends like William B. Travis, Jim Bowie, and Davy Crocket laid down their lives at the Alamo and inspired thousands of brave fighters to take up arms to free Texas from the oppressive regime of General Santa Anna. #texasindependenceday #texasğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± #texas
After General Sam Houston led the Texas Army to victory, he became the first President of the Republic of Texas.
His words â€“ â€˜govern wisely and as little as possibleâ€™ â€“ still ring true today. Because the Lone Star State still follows this principle, Texas has become an economic powerhouse.
Thanks to limited government and ingenuity of hardworking Texans, the Lone Star State has one of the top performing economies in the nation and is consistently ranked the number one best state for business. The result? More jobs and higher wages.
Sam Houston and those he led risked everything to make freedom a reality for generations of Texans. Today, we celebrate and honor that sacrifice.
To every Texan, I wish you a very Happy Texas Independence Day.

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke out against inequality, against injustice.

Today we celebrate Martin Luther King. In my office, I have the busts of three transformative heroes: a bust of Winston Churchill, a bust of Ronald Reagan, and a bust of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. All three fought for freedom, understood the power of words, and vision, and the power of speaking truth.

Dr. King urged America to honor its â€˜sacred obligation' and he advocated for our inalienable rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. And he courageously called on his fellow Americans, â€˜to lift our nation from the quicksand of racial injustice to the solid rock of brotherhood.' Dr. King inspired men and women across the country and around the world.

He appealed to the soul of our nation and asked us to have â€˜the courage to face the uncertainties of the future,' â€˜as we continue our forward stride toward the city of freedom.' From the dark cells of a Birmingham jail to the steps of the Lincoln Memorial - Dr. King spoke courageously and humbly he spoke out against inequality, against injustice. And his vision transformed America.

As we today honor the memory of Dr. King - of Reverend King - may we never forget our responsibility to pursue truth and justice as he did, and to work together to secure the blessings of liberty for every single American.

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Today, House Democrats are finally handing the reins of their partisan show trial over to the Senate. For months, the American people have been lectured on the critical urgency of impeaching President Trump. For more than three weeks, Nancy Pelosi dragged her feet, refusing to send the Articles over to the Senate. The reason is that the Articles fail to meet the constitutional standard for impeachment. They do not allege a single crime was committed â€“ not even a speeding ticket.
Itâ€™s been disheartening to watch House Democrats subject our constitutional process and the President to relentless abuse and partisan gamesmanship for blatantly political purposes. That pattern will not continue in the Senate.
Make no mistake; the Senate will give President Trump and the American people a fair trial. One that follows precedent and respects due process. Unlike the House, we will be fair, give both sides a full opportunity to present their case, and allow the President to defend himself. The Senate should do its job quickly. I look forward to reviewing the evidence, voting on these facially-deficient Articles, and continuing to deliver on the promises we made to the American people, like securing our Southern border, reducing the burden of federal regulations, and creating more economic opportunity for the hardworking men and women of this country. #senate #impeachment #impeachmenttrial #articlesofimpeachment #respectdueprocess

comments: ['really great to see ted blaming a murder on politics.', '@magan_wiggins', '"The impeachment inquiry has found that President Trump, personally and acting through agents within and outside of the U.S. government, solicited the interference of a foreign government, Ukraine, to benefit his reelection. In pressuring President Zelensky to carry out his demand, President Trump withheld a White House meeting desperately sought by the Ukrainian President, and critical U.S. military assistance to fight Russian aggression in eastern Ukraine. The President engaged in this course of conduct for the benefit of his own presidential reelection, to harm the election prospects of a political rival, and to influence our nationâ€™s upcoming presidential election to his advantage. In doing so, the President placed his own personal and political interests above the national interests of the United States, sought to undermine the integrity of the U.S. presidential election process, and endangered U.S. national security." - The Impeachment Inquiry Report.', '"At the center of this investigation is the memorandum prepared following President Trumpâ€™s July 25, 2019, phone call with Ukraineâ€™s President, which the White House declassified and released under significant public pressure. The call record alone is stark evidence of misconduct; a demonstration of the Presidentâ€™s prioritization of his personal political benefit over the national interest. In response to President Zelenskyâ€™s appreciation for vital U.S. military assistance, which President Trump froze without explanation, President Trump asked for â€œa favor thoughâ€: two specific investigations designed to assist his reelection efforts. Our investigation determined that this telephone call was neither the start nor the end of President Trumpâ€™s efforts to bend U.S. foreign policy for his personal gain. Rather, it was a dramatic crescendo within a months-long campaign driven by President Trump in which senior U.S. officials, including the Vice President, the Secretary of State, the Acting Chief of Staff, the Secretary of Energy, and others were either knowledgeable of or active participants in an effort to extract from a foreign nation the personal political benefits sought by the President." - The Impeachment Inquiry Report.', '"The investigation revealed the nature and extent of the Presidentâ€™s misconduct, notwithstanding an unprecedented campaign of obstruction by the President and his Administration to prevent the Committees from obtaining documentary evidence and testimony. A dozen witnesses followed President Trumpâ€™s orders, defying voluntary requests and lawful subpoenas, and refusing to testify. The White House, Department of State, Department of Defense, Office of Management and Budget, and Department of Energy refused to produce a single document in response to our subpoenas. Ultimately, this sweeping effort to stonewall the House of Representativesâ€™ â€œsole Power of Impeachmentâ€ under the Constitution failed because witnesses courageously came forward and testified in response to lawful process. The report that follows was only possible because of their sense of duty and devotion to their country and its Constitution." - The Impeachment Inquiry Report.', '"Given the proximate threat of further presidential attempts to solicit foreign interference in our next election, we cannot wait to make a referral until our efforts to obtain additional testimony and documents wind their way through the courts. The evidence of the Presidentâ€™s misconduct is overwhelming, and so too is the evidence of his obstruction of Congress. Indeed, it would be hard to imagine a stronger or more complete case of obstruction than that demonstrated by the President since the inquiry began. The damage the President has done to our relationship with a key strategic partner will be remedied over time, and Ukraine continues to enjoy strong bipartisan support in Congress. But the damage to our system of checks and balances, and to the balance of power within our three branches of government, will be long-lasting and potentially irrevocable if the Presidentâ€™s ability to stonewall Congress goes unchecked. Any future President will feel empowered to resist an investigation into their own wrongdoing, malfeasance, or corruption, and the result will be a nation at far greater risk of all three." - The Impeachment Inquiry Report.', '"The efforts to involve Ukraine in our 2020 presidential election were undertaken by a President who himself was elected in 2016 with the benefit of an unprecedented and sweeping campaign of election interference undertaken by Russia in his favor, and which the President welcomed and utilized. Having witnessed the degree to which interference by a foreign power in 2016 harmed our democracy, President Trump cannot credibly claim ignorance to its pernicious effects. Even more pointedly, the Presidentâ€™s July call with Ukrainian President Zelensky, in which he solicited an investigation to damage his most feared 2020 opponent, came the day after Special Counsel Robert Mueller testified to Congress about Russiaâ€™s efforts to damage his 2016 opponent and his urgent warning of the dangers of further foreign interference in the next election. With this backdrop, the solicitation of new foreign intervention was the act of a president unbound, not one chastened by experience. It was the act of a president who viewed himself as unaccountable and determined to use his vast official powers to secure his reelection." - The Impeachment Inquiry Report.', 'ğŸŒ·ğŸ‘‘', '@sentedcruz please,Tell the Democrats that the Iranian people do not want this cruel mullahs regime.ğŸ™', 'Have you been gaining weight ted?', 'ğŸ˜', "Now that's awesome. Today, we stand together in remembrance of the fallen, and show a profound gratitude for the men and women who selflessly answered the call to defend our country. The service of our U.S. Armed Forces, law enforcement, and first responders ensures that our nation continues to represent a beacon of freedom for all, even when our resolve is tested. name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Thirty years ago thousands of Chinese protestors gathered in Tiananmen Square demanding freedom. The Chinese Communist Party and the People's Liberation Army slaughtered them. To this day we donâ€™t know how many perished on â€˜that bloody dawn,â€™ as Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo described it. Today, the CCP continues its war against the people of China and brands entire religions and ethnicities as security threats to be imprisoned, brutally tortured, and if necessary murdered.
The Party treats the rest of the world with similar disdain. It seeks to silence free speech in America and around the world while it steals technology and intimidates its neighbors. Xi Jinping threatens Taiwan with military invasion while eroding Hong Kongâ€™s autonomy. Even so, the ghost of Tiananmen still haunts the Communist Party. Truth is stronger than lies, and light overcomes darkness. Dictators fear their people. There is power in reminding the Communist Party about this day. America must always stand with the people of China. We must never stop fighting for the democracy so many gave their lives for 30 years ago today. #tiananmensquare #tiananmen30

name: Ted Cruz
caption: It was an honor today to have the opportunity to address the United States Agency for Global Mediaâ€™s â€˜Media for Democracy Forum.â€™ There, I highlighted the roles of a free press in defending truth and promoting freedom: â€œOur principles can tear down walls, can topple tyrannies, can promote freedom. America should consistently be a voice for freedom. We should be a voice for human rights. We should be a voice for democracy. Because that truth is powerful and it can transform the world. Thatâ€™s also where an American free press and the USAGM come in play. Now to be clear, we donâ€™t ask journalists to promote the viewpoint of the United States government. There are plenty of countries in the world where governments run their media, and the media is little more than a propaganda outlet for whatever the policy views are of the particular regime in power. Instead, we believe in a different kind of press, one that aligns with American principles. Itâ€™s a testament to our system of government that we encourage and protect dissent. That we encourage and protect a free media because freedom depends upon a free media.â€

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Today @senatorjontester and I introduced a bipartisan bill that would give qualified members of the National Guard and Reserves a tiered preference in hiring for federal civil service jobs. The Military Reserve Jobs Act would help promote the hiring of National Guard members and Reservists into the federal workforce.
The men and women of the armed forces, including the National Guardsmen and Reservists, are our nationâ€™s greatest asset. They preserve our freedoms and ensure our military readiness. I am proud to lead this effort again this year and appreciate the leadership of Sen. Tester and his strong support for our nation's veterans. This legislation would ensure these brave men and women have the same opportunities for federal employment as veterans of other military branches, and am hopeful Congress will move quickly to pass this important bill.

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Proud to join Sens. Tom Cotton, John Cornyn & Marco Rubio in sending a letter to President Trump urging him to send battle-hardened ISIS fighters currently detained in Syria to Guantanamo Bay.

Doing so would prevent these dangerous terrorists from being released to commit further acts of terror. 10 years ago, President Obama signed a misguided executive order ordering the closure of the detention facility at Guantanamo Bay. This executive order drew sharp criticism from elected Republican officials on Capitol Hill â€“ and rightly so. The subsequent rise and fall of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria has only underscored the need for a detention facility in Guantanamo Bay.

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
This week @repjasonsmith and I reintroduced the Student Empowerment Act, which would expand 529 College Savings Plans to include K-12 elementary and secondary school expenses for public, private, and religious schools, including homeschool students. This bill builds upon my Student Opportunity Amendment, which was signed into law in December 2017, by allowing all students â€“ including public, private, religious, and homeschool students â€“ to use 529 savings accounts to cover eligible educational expenses.

Under the Student Opportunity Amendment, homeschool families were wrongly and cynically excluded by Senate Democrats, leaving them ineligible to utilize the expanded usage of 529 savings accounts. This bill re-includes homeschoolers, and empowers every family with access to an education that truly fits their childâ€™s needs. I am proud to champion school choice with Rep. Smith, and am hopeful my colleagues will move swiftly to empower all students.

Dwight Eisenhower appointed pro-choice Justices William Brennan (1956) and Potter Stewart (1958) to the Supreme Court. Wade was decided on January 22, 1973 with 5 Republican appointed Justices voting in favor of it (Brennan, Stewart, Burger, Blackmun and Powell). President Gerald Ford admitted to being pro-choice and made Nelson Rockefeller his Vice President. Ford appointed pro-choice Justice John Paul Stevens to the Supreme Court in 1975. Ronald Reagan appointed pro-choice Justice Sandra Day O'Connor in 1981 who was also confirmed by a Republican controlled Senate. Reagan also appointed pro-choice Justice Anthony Kennedy in 1988. George H.W. Bush appointed pro-choice David Souter to the highest court in 1990. Roe v. Wade was further solidified as precedence in Planned Parenthood v. Casey on June 29, 1992. Republican appointed Justices Blackmun, Stevens, O'Connor, Kennedy and Souter voted in favor of the Casey decision that upheld Roe. name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Today I reintroduced the Ensuring Lawful Collection of Hidden Assets to Provide Order (EL CHAPO) Act. The bill would reserve any amounts forfeited to the U.S. Government as a result of the criminal prosecution of â€œEl Chapoâ€ (formally named Joaquin Archivaldo Guzman Lorea) and other drug lords for border security assets and the completion of the wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

Congress has a clear mandate from the American people: secure the border and build the wall. Ensuring the safety and security of Texans is one of my top priorities. Indeed, I have long called for building a wall as a necessary step in defending our border. Fourteen billion dollars will go a long way to secure our southern border, and hinder the illegal flow of drugs, weapons, and individuals. By leveraging any criminally forfeited assets of El Chapo and other murderous drug lords, we can offset the cost of securing our border and make meaningful progress toward delivering on the promises made to the American people.

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
In this season of hope, we celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ. The promised Savior, born in Bethlehem, came that we may know Him and his everlasting love and redemption.
Evidence of Christâ€™s love can be found all across the Lone Star State. Just this week, high school students and others volunteered their time with Lubbockâ€™s Meals on Wheels to distribute more than 400 boxes of supplies for seniors. In Laredo, United Middle School students collected presents for children living at Casa De Misericordia, a shelter for survivors of domestic violence. And nearly 1,800 children in Georgetown received gifts from the Williamson County Sheriff's Office. All around us, there are stories of Texans sharing the joy of Christmas with their neighbors.
We also remember our servicemen and women who are spending the holiday season far away from home at sea or deployed in a foreign land. We pray for their safe return. And we remember their families, who sacrifice enormously for our great country.
Heidi and I wish you and your family a very Merry Christmas and a blessed New Year. May God continue to bless the great state of Texas and the United States of America.

name: Ted Cruz
caption:
Today the Senate passed Sens. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.), Ed Markey (D-Mass), and my bipartisan Space Frontier Act (S.3277) by a unanimous vote of approval. In July, we introduced this legislation to fortify Americaâ€™s leadership in space exploration, continue operations for the International Space Station (ISS) through 2030, and reign in overreaching regulations to support further development of the commercial space sector.

For over half a century the United States has been the global leader in space. The Space Frontier Act not only ensures that the United States will remain the global leader in space exploration, but also reduces regulatory barriers to allow a vibrant commercial economy to flourish in space. The Space Frontier Act takes the critical step of continuing the operations and utilization of the International Space Station through 2030, ensures that the United States wonâ€™t cede low-Earth orbit to China, enacts meaningful reforms to modernize our nationâ€™s launch and re-entry regulations, and streamlines nongovernmental Earth observation regulations. I am proud to have worked with Senators Nelson and Markey on this bipartisan legislation, and urge my House colleagues to take swift action to pass our bill and send it to the Presidentâ€™s desk to be signed into law.

Â· He opposed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 & the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
Â· In the 1964 presidential election Reagan campaigned vigorously for the KKK endorsed Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona who was among 6 GOP senators to vote against the Civil Rights Act of 1964 in the Senate.

Â· He attempted to put a racist - Robert Bork on the Supreme Court in 1987. Bork like Reagan, Goldwater & Strom Thurmond opposed the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Senate voted to reject Bork's nomination 58-42.

Â· October 23, 1983 - Two Iranian supported terrorist truck bombers blew up the U.S. marine barracks in Beirut, Lebanon killing 241 American marines and 58 French paratroopers. The marines were not even allowed to load their guns because of Reagan's rules of engagement. Reagan never retaliated against Iran, instead he ordered a full retreat by February 1984.
Â· December 12, 1983 - Iran was behind the bombing of the U.S. embassy in Kuwait City, Kuwait which killed 5 people. Reagan never retaliated against Iran.
Â· September 20, 1984 - Iranian backed terrorists bombed the U.S. embassy annex in Beirut killing 24 people (2 were Americans). Reagan never ordered any retaliation against Iran.
Â· May 17, 1987 - an Iraqi fighter jet opened fire on the USS Stark in the Persian Gulf killing 37 American sailors. Reagan never retaliated against Iraq.
Â· December 21, 1988 - Libyan terrorists bombed Pan Am 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland killing 270 people on board and on the ground (190 were Americans). It was the worst aircraft disaster in the history of the U.K. Reagan never retaliated against Libya.
Â· Reagan lifted Jimmy Carter's grain embargo on the Soviet Union upon coming into office in 1981.
Â· International terrorist organizations thrived during his two terms. Hezbollah was founded in 1985, Hamas in 1987 and Al-Qaeda in 1988. Â· Reagan also sold military equipment to both Iraq and Iran.
Anyone can see Reagan did not care about Americans or American interests overseas."]
